title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998". The Congress finds that there are over 600 different Federal financial assistance programs with duplicative and burdensome administrative requirements, hindering cost-effective service delivery. Streamlining these procedures will improve services to the public. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, key definitions include Director as the head of the Office of Management and Budget, Federal agency as any agency defined under title 5, Federal financial assistance as aid provided to non-Federal entities, local government as a political subdivision of a State, and non-Federal entity as a State, local government, or nonprofit organization. The term "nonprofit organization" refers to an entity operated for public interest, not for profit, and uses proceeds to maintain its operations. The curr_chunk defines terms related to governmental entities, including "State," "Tribal government," and "Uniform administrative rule." The curr_chunk defines a "uniform administrative rule" as a government-wide rule for achieving national policy objectives across multiple Federal financial assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment to streamline application procedures, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, designate a lead official, and allow electronic application and reporting for financial assistance programs. The agency must comply with various responsibilities under the Act, including allowing electronic application and reporting for financial assistance programs, ensuring timely and high-quality information from recipients, and setting annual goals to measure performance. If agencies cannot meet these requirements, the Director must report to the Senate and Governmental Affairs Committee. The Government Performance and Results Act requires agencies to develop and implement plans. If agencies are unable to comply, the Director may extend the deadline by up to 12 months. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register for public comment and hold public forums when possible. Each Federal agency must submit their plan to the Director and Congress, report annually on its implementation, and consult with non-Federal entities during development and implementation. Public comment on the plan is required through the Federal Register and public forums. The agency must report annually to the Director and Congress on the plan's implementation and performance in meeting specified goals. The report can be included in general management reports as required by law. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and non-Federal entities, shall direct and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system will allow non-Federal entities to apply for and manage funding from multiple programs administered by different agencies. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and non-Federal entities, shall establish a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system aims to streamline administrative procedures, reporting requirements, and improve coordination among different Federal agencies. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to improve coordination and information sharing for Federal financial assistance programs. Agencies are required to submit plans and reports for review. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to assist in carrying out responsibilities under this Act. Agencies must submit information and reports for review. The Director has the authority to exempt Federal agencies or programs from the Act's requirements if deemed necessary. A list of exempted agencies will be made public through OMB's Internet site. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act. The evaluation will assess the Act's effectiveness, agency performance, and coordination among various entities. Recommendations for further implementation will be made. The Director will evaluate agency performance in achieving goals and objectives stated in agency plans. Coordination among Federal agencies, State, local, and tribal governments, and nonprofit organizations in implementing the Act will also be assessed. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION.

Federal agencies can gather necessary information for reviewing the financial integrity of activities receiving Federal financial assistance.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW.

There is no judicial review of compliance with this Act, and no provisions create enforceable rights through legal action.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

This Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET. SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

This Act does not deviate from statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET.

The Act will be effective upon enactment and will expire five years later.
